awd_titl_txt: Quantum Phase Transition in one-dimensional superconductors
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-technical Abstract:
The overall goal of the project is to understand how superconductivity in nanowires is affected by their geometry, material properties, and the presence of an external magnetic field. The knowledge of how these factors influence the properties of the superconducting nanowires is needed for improvement of nanowire-based single-photon detectors and for downscaling of classical and quantum superconducting circuits. The project is also important for fundamental science. Our team recently discovered that, similar to classical water-ice phase transition, nanowires also undergo a phase transition; because it occurs at zero temperature, however, it belongs to the class of quantum phase transitions (QPT). One of the primary goals of the project is to uncover the as yet unknown nature of this transition. One-dimensional systems, of which superconducting nanowires are a representative example, play a special role in physics since they often allow for easier theoretical description than their counterparts in higher dimensions. Hence the project has a potential to advance understanding physics of superconducting films and other systems where QPTs occur, such as magnetic materials, liquid crystals, and cold atomic gases. The educational component of the project includes training of students in nanofabrication and precision electrical instrumentation and service of a PI as a research adviser for undergraduate female students participating in the University of Utah ACCESS program. The public outreach includes oral and exhibit presentations on superconductivity and nanoscience, carried out both at the University of Utah and at the Natural History Museum of Utah, as a part of the NSF-funded Portal for the Public program.

Technical Abstract:
The team's research is focused on four problems in 1D superconductivity. (i) The experimentally determined suppression of critical temperature in superconducting nanowires is 100-fold stronger than the prediction from current theories. To resolve this problem, the team will systematically study the effect of geometrical confinement on critical temperature (by transport measurements), on superconducting gap (by tunneling), and on superfluid density (by kinetic inductance measurements) in MoGe and Al nanowires. The goal is to identify leading mechanisms of the suppression and, in collaboration with theorists, develop a correct fermionic theory for nanowires and films. (ii) Upon application of a magnetic field, MoGe nanowires undergo a quantum phase transition of yet unknown nature. To uncover the mechanism of this QPT, we will carry out transport, tunneling and kinetic inductance measurements on nanowires in a magnetic field. The combined scaling of the magnetoresistance of a series of nanowires will be used to find constraints on the scaling function. (iii) A series of nanowires with an intentionally inhomogeneous order parameter will be fabricated and studied. The objective is to create a system where the physics of the QPT is strongly dominated by bosonic processes (phase slips). (iv) A high-frequency technique capable of the detection of individual phase slips will be developed. The goal is to probe the regime of ultra-low phase slip rate (down to 1 Hz) and verify if there exist temporal correlations caused by phase-slip/anti-phase-slip interactions and/or by phase-slip avalanches.

Quantum Phase Transition in Superconducting Nanowires (NSF award 1611421, A. Rogachev. University of Utah)

Intellectual merit metrics

When a material or quantum object is cooled to ZERO temperature and is acted upon, say by pressure and magnetic field, it can transform from one state of matter to another, for example, from ferromagnetic state to non-magnetic state. Such transformations are termed quantum phase transitions (QPTs); they are widespread in nature and, surprisingly, can have universal behavior in very diverse objects, such as nuclei, stars, ordinary materials found on Earth and man-made nanostructures. Many important characteristics of QPTs are not well-understood. The subject of our research, nanowires and thin films, undergo superconductor-to-normal metal QPT under the action of magnetic field and/or by size reduction. Our team uses the state-of-the-art electron beam lithography to fabricate uniform nanowires with diameter 10 nm, which is roughly 50 atoms placed side-to-side. (A picture of nanowires used in this study is submitted with the report). We carefully study the effects of QPT on the finite-temperature conductivity in these nanowires with the goal to uncover both the universal character of QPT, and also specific microscopic processes that govern the transition in superconducting systems.

The funding provided by NSF award 1611421 allowed us to make an important discovery that magnetic-field driven QPT in nanowires occurs via so called pair-breaking mechanism. Our nanowires are so narrow, that electrons move in them just in one direction ? along the nanowire length. That is why they are termed one-dimensional superconductors. One-dimensional systems are much easy to understand theoretically then corresponding systems in higher dimensions, so we were able to compare our data with and exact critical theory of QPT developed by a group of theorists from Harvard. Excellent agreement has been found. (The figure is added to the report.)
              Our group has also completed and brought to publications several other studies of nanowires. In addition, four papers on noise properties on silicon and perovskite solar cells have been published.  The results of our work have been presented at ten domestic and international conferences.   

Broad impact metrics

Besides posing interesting fundamental questions, superconducting nanowires have immediate application in detectors used for astronomical observation and secure quantum communication. Understanding properties of superconducting nanowire is also important for the continuing downscaling of the superconducting processors operating both on conventional and quantum computing principles.

Graduate and undergraduate students have been trained and obtained the skills in 1) low-noise measurements, 2) operation and design of high-vacuum equipment, 3) general operation in machine-shop, parts design using Autodesk inventor, 4) small circuit electronics, design and processing, 5) semiconductor wafer processing and film deposition, 6) operation of the He-3, He-4 and Nitrogen flow cryostat. 7) nano-fabrication, Scanning microscopy, e-beam lithography. All our undergraduate students worked on independent research and/or instrumentation project created by PI. The past funding period was particularly successful in students? achievements. Three of our undergraduate students have entered graduate schools, one graduate student got Master degree and another PhD degree.

PI served as the Physics Department representative at National Conference of SACNAS (Society for Advancement of Chicanos and Native Americans in Science) in October of 2017. Kevin Davenport, a graduate student fully supported by the award, has received the AAAS Mass Media Science and Engineering Fellowship.  Kevin has also participated in the University of Utah INSPIRE program, wherein scientists go into the county jail and state prison and give science lectures to the incarcerated.  The group has been involved in an interactive exhibit based on the current research in the PI?s group to be presented to the visitors of Natural History Museum of Utah and to museum employees and volunteers as part of their continuing education lecture series.  The PI and his students have served as volunteer judges at Utah Science Olympiads and Undergraduate Research Symposiums. PI and his students have also hosted numerous tours of the lab and other facilities in the Physics Department. The tours were attended by undergraduate students, local high school students and members of scout clubs.
